title: How Wish Built (and Fumbled) a Dollar Store for the Internet
abstract: The number of users has plummeted, and its stock price has dropped. Former employees point to an emphasis on short-term growth over customer service.
byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Sapna Maheshwari

title: Officials Balked at a Drug Company’s Tax Shelter. Auditors Approved It Anyway.
abstract: Court documents show the potential conflicts of interest when accounting firms simultaneously help clients avoid taxes and audit their finances.

multimedia.caption: Murray Kessler, chief executive of Perrigo. The I.R.S. is challenging Perrigo’s tax arrangement on sales of a popular drug, omeprazole.
Murray Kessler, chief executive of Perrigo. The I.R.S. is challenging Perrigo’s tax arrangement on sales of a popular drug, omeprazole.

title: Siberia or Japan? Expert Google Maps Players Can Tell at a Glimpse.
abstract: In a game called GeoGuessr, competitors try to pinpoint where in the world a Google Street View image has been taken. Some can do it in seconds.

multimedia.caption: “It’s like a magician,” said Trevor Rainbolt, a prominent player of a quirky game called GeoGuessr. “To the magician, the trick is easy, but to everyone else, it’s a lot harder.”
multimedia.copyright: Jack Bool for The New York Times

title: Fed Moves Toward Another Big Rate Increase as Inflation Lingers
abstract: As the Federal Reserve battles rapid inflation, officials are likely to stay on an aggressive path even as signs of economic cooling emerge.

multimedia.caption: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, has said central bankers will debate between a 0.5- or 0.75-percentage-point increase at their July meeting.
The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, has said central bankers will debate between a 0.5- or 0.75-percentage-point increase at their July meeting.

title: For People Just Leaving Prison, a Novel Kind of Support: Cash
abstract: Joining a raft of initiatives aimed at helping the formerly incarcerated, a program gives money to defray expenses they face, including court fines and rent.

multimedia.caption: Alwin Jacob Smith received cash after leaving prison, helping him repair a car to drive to job interviews, and eventually land a $17-an-hour job. “I wouldn’t be afloat right now” if not for the monetary lifeline, he said.
multimedia.copyright: Eric Thayer for The New York Times

abstract: The drop was another fallout of rising inflation and widespread economic uncertainty, and a retreat after years of a funding boom.

title: Chinese Police Database Was Left Unsecured Long Before Hackers Seized It
abstract: The breach is “a big black eye” for the Chinese security apparatus, one expert says, exposing the risk of the state’s vast effort to amass citizens’ personal data.
byline: By Amy Qin, John Liu and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: A police car patrols in Shanghai in May.
A police car patrols in Shanghai in May.

title: Disinformation Has Become Another Untouchable Problem in Washington
abstract: Numerous federal agencies agree that widely promoted falsehoods threaten the nation’s security. Doing something about them is another matter.

title: Europe, Facing Energy Shortages, Moves to Shore Up Providers
abstract: Berlin and Paris are preparing bailouts as Europe braces for further cuts to gas supplies next week and economists warn of a recession.

title: Jobs Aplenty, but a Shortage of Care Keeps Many Women From Benefiting
abstract: A lack of child care and elder care options has forced some women to limit their hours or sidelined them altogether, hurting their career prospects.

title: An Irish regulator puts Facebook data policies back in spotlight.
abstract: A decision from Ireland’s Data Protection Commission is likely to add to pressure on U.S. and European negotiators to finalize a deal on trans-Atlantic data transfers.

title: How Unlikely Is It That the Audits of Comey and McCabe Were a Coincidence? A Statistical Exploration.
abstract: The chances are minuscule. But minuscule is not zero.

title: Behind the fight between Ben & Jerry’s and its owner, Unilever.
abstract: The ice cream maker is suing its corporate parent in an effort to stop sales in Israeli-occupied territories, thanks to an unusual deal that gives the founders control of the brand.

abstract: Markets in Britain rose slightly after Boris Johnson said he would step down, but global economic factors have been more important to investors.

title: Renters Face Fiercest Competition in Florida and the Northeast
abstract: Demand for apartments in Florida has intensified, followed by markets in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, as Americans embrace remote work.

title: Parents Sue TikTok, Saying Children Died After Viewing ‘Blackout Challenge’
abstract: The suit, involving girls ages 8 and 9, claims TikTok knew or should have known that its product was “addictive” and was directing children to dangerous content.

title: What Amazon Prime’s Deal With Grubhub Means for Consumers
abstract: A new collaboration between the retailing giant and the food distribution service includes free restaurant delivery for Prime members.

abstract: Previously, only doctors, nurses or physician assistants were allowed to prescribe the treatment, known as Paxlovid.

title: Fed officials, spooked by data, fretted in June about inflation becoming entrenched.
abstract: Central bankers raised rates by the most since 1994 last month, and minutes from the gathering explained their logic.

title: Her ‘Chagall’ Is Headed for the Trash. How’s That for Caveat Emptor?
abstract: Stephanie Clegg paid $90,000 for a Marc Chagall painting at a Sotheby’s auction in 1994. It was reappraised for $100,000 in 2008. Now an expert panel in France wants to destroy it as a fake.
